Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Scientific Computation at Ohio Wesleyan University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the renewal of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site at Ohio Wesleyan University. Each undergraduate participant will work on a ten-week research project under the guidance of an Ohio Wesleyan University faculty member in one of the following disciplines: physics, astronomy, computer science, mathematics/statistics, or neuroscience. The program will help to develop a better infrastructure for research and education, and develop the STEM workforce that is needed for the Nation.


The projects will focus on one or more aspects of scientific computation, such as: numerical (coding in a "traditional" programming language), symbolic (using a computer algebra program such as MathematicaÂ®), and data visualization. An important goal of the REU site is to make participants aware of the ability of computational techniques to cross disciplinary boundaries. Weekly meetings, in which individual research groups give progress reports and all participants are able to discuss the projects, will foster a sense of community among the participants and point out the strengths of computational techniques to tackle problems in varying disciplines. A series of weekly, half-hour, faculty-led seminars will introduce participants to widely used computational tools. A research symposium will be held at the end of the research period for participants to present their results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project's main objective is to give undergraduates interested in the mathematical and physical sciences experience with computational techniques as applied to cutting-edge research problems. During the summers of 2017-2019, 22 students from colleges and universities distributed around the country visited the Ohio Wesleyan University (OWU) campus to study research problems under the guidance of OWU faculty members in order to learn about computational methods (numerical, symbolic, and graphical) and how those methods can be used to solve a wide class of problems. Students, most for the first time, were exposed to an intensive, ten-week research experience that gave them an accurate representation of the nature of scientific research and also, through workshops and presentations by faculty and other students in the program, showed them how many techniques can make headway on diverse problems across several scientific disciplines. Students also receive guidance on careers in science, preparation for graduate school, and tips for giving effective scientific presentations.

Six faculty research mentors from the departments of Physics/Astronomy and Mathematics/Computer Science guided research students on the following projects:

  • The Anti-Vaccination Movement's Affect on the World (Mathematics/Neuroscience)
  • Artificial Intelligence for Modern Board Games (Computer Science)
  • Sampling Distribution of Regression Statistics with Data Subjected to Type II Censoring (Statistics)
  • Search for Exotic Shapes in the "Wild West" of the Nuclear Landscape (Nuclear Physics)
  • Stellar Surface Imaging via Light Curve Inversion (Astrophysics)
  • Theoretical Notions of Ecological Stability and Their Relation to Temporal Variability (Mathematics)

Students presented their results in oral or poster format at a final symposium on the last day of each summer program. The Ohio College Summer Research Symposium is typically held each July on the OWU campus. Summer research students from other Ohio colleges and universities (Denison University, Kenyon College, Oberlin College, Ohio Northern University, Wittenberg University, and the College of Wooster), are invited to join the OWU/REU research students at the symposium to share the results of their research. These presentations have been recorded and can be viewed on YouTube. Many REU students also presented their results at regional and national conferences such as: The Young Mathematicians Conference, Meeting of the American Physical Society Nuclear Physics Division, Meeting of the American Astronomical Society, Meeting of the American Geophysical Union, and the Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics.

Most REU participants pursue graduate studies in physics, astronomy, mathematics, or computer science and are interested in a career in scientific research and teaching at the university level. Others obtain employment in their chosen professions. Society clearly benefits from the addition of talented and well-trained individuals such as these to the scientific workforce.

Example Project Description: The World Health Organization (WHO) has highlighted "Vaccination Hesitancy" as a threat to global health in 2019. Many children in the US and abroad are vaccinated at a young age for a variety of diseases. Yet, we are seeing a rise in the number of cases of vaccine-preventable diseases previously deemed nearly-eradicated. Mathematical modeling can provide a framework for simulating the impact of disease spread and anti-vaccination sentiment on a community. A common approach is to use agent-based models and network modeling techniques to develop accurate and insightful pictures of the real-world situation. In fact, two separate, but strongly related network models: one to follow disease outbreak and the other to map trends in vaccination hesitancy, may be an effective approach here. 

Students will conduct a literature search to obtain biological and sociological details about a vaccine, the disease(s) it prevents, and common beliefs in support of and against it. They will investigate previously established modeling efforts on the disease and vaccine. Additionally, students will research standard modeling approaches for idea spread across a population. They will develop agent-based models and write a program to implement them using MATLAB or C++. Features of differential equations or stochastic processes often come into play during the modeling phase. Students will develop appropriate questions pertaining to the problem at hand and use their model to investigate possible answers to their inquiries.
